title: 108_s2205
content:
There are no paragraphs provided in the prev_chunk, so I will summarize the curr_chunk directly.

Summarized chunk:
"SECTION 1. FINDINGS." "Ukraine allows citizens the right to emigrate with minimal taxes, complies with freedom of emigration requirements, and is committed to democratic institutions and human rights as an OSCE member." Ukraine has made progress in meeting international commitments in its recent Parliamentary elections, but significant shortcomings remain, including illegal interference and intimidation against opposition figures. The country has also enacted legislation to protect against discrimination and violence based on national, racial, ethnic, or religious grounds. Ukraine has made progress in combating ethnic and religious intolerance, including restitution of religious properties confiscated during the Soviet era. They have received normal trade relations treatment and are working towards accession to the World Trade Organization. Ukraine has made commitments to resolve issues related to access of US agricultural products, intellectual property rights, tariff reductions, trade in services, agricultural subsidies, and customs procedures. The country has enacted protections for labor rights but gaps remain in enforcement. Ukraine is committed to respecting freedom of the press and has positive relations with neighboring countries. They aim for European integration while ensuring democracy and prosperity for citizens. Ukraine has cooperated with the United States in peacekeeping operations in Europe and fighting international terrorism. The President may determine that title IV of the Trade Act of 1974 should no longer apply to Ukraine and extend permanent normal trade relations treatment to the country's products. This would cease the application of title IV to Ukraine. The Congress urges Ukraine to fulfill its commitments to the OSCE, including promoting free emigration, safeguarding religious liberty, combating discrimination, and respecting media freedoms. They also support Ukraine in improving in various areas and making progress in enacting and enforcing protection measures. The Congress urges Ukraine to fulfill its commitments to the OSCE, including promoting free emigration, safeguarding religious liberty, combating discrimination, and respecting media freedoms. They also support Ukraine in making progress in enacting and enforcing protection measures for intellectual property rights, resolving trade disputes, and monitoring human rights, rule of law, and media freedoms in the country. SEC. 4. REPORTING REQUIREMENT.

Reports under the International Religious Freedom Act of 1998 must assess issues outlined in section 3(1).

SEC. 5. CONTINUED ENJOYMENT OF RIGHTS UNDER THE JUNE 23, 1992, BILATERAL TRADE AGREEMENT.

The trade agreement between the US and Ukraine from June 23, 1992, remains in force, granting the US rights to use safeguard rules against import surges from Ukraine.

SEC. 6. EXERCISE OF CONGRESSIONAL OVERSIGHT OVER WTO ACCESSION NEGOTIATIONS. The President must notify Congress within 5 days of a bilateral agreement with Ukraine on WTO accession terms. A report on the agreement must be transmitted to Congress within 15 days. If a resolution of disapproval is introduced within 30 days, it will be considered. The term "resolution of disapproval" refers to a joint resolution by Congress expressing that the agreement between the US and Ukraine on WTO terms does not sufficiently benefit the US. Resolutions of disapproval can be introduced by any House member, referred to the Committees on Ways and Means and Rules, and cannot be amended. The resolution of disapproval can be introduced by any Senate member, referred to the Committee on Finance, and cannot be amended. The rules of the House of Representatives and Senate apply to the resolution of disapproval in the same way as to other resolutions. The rules of the House of Representatives and Senate apply to the resolution of disapproval in the same way as to other resolutions, with the recognition of the constitutional right of either House to change the rules relating to procedures at any time.
